headline: Speakeasy: 'Avatar' vs. 'Gone With the Wind
summary: Molly Haskell, author of "Frankly, My Dear: Gone with the Wind Revisited" looks at the similarities and differences between the 2009 sci-fi blockbuster and 1939 civil war epic.

headline: Bridges, Bullock Win SAG Awards
summary: Jeff Bridges of "Crazy Heart" and Sandra Bullock of "The Blind Side" claimed top acting honors at the SAG Awards, building momentum for possible Academy Awards glory for the two stars.

headline: Asia Sinks on U.S. Bank Rules
summary: Asian stock markets tumbled on concerns over proposed U.S. banking curbs and the prospect of China rolling out more measures to cool its economy. For the week, the Nikkei fell 3.6%.

headline: Victims: Archbishop Joseph Serge Miot
summary: Joseph Serge Miot was killed in last week's earthquake. "He had no other house but at the archdiocese. That's why he died here," said a priest who worked with him.

headline: Haiti to End Search for Survivors
summary: The Haitian government prepared Friday to call off the search for survivors of last week's killer earthquake.

headline: The Evolution of Clubhouses
summary: Real-estate bust, changing tastes have golf-focused buildings making a comeback.

headline: Sister Marie Claude, Nun, Beekeeper
summary: Sister Marie Claude of the Daughters of Wisdom organized events at her convent, including a pastoral retreat four days before the earthquake in which she was killed.

headline: Populist Surge Eases Support for Bernanke
summary: Bernanke faced ebbing support for a second term as Fed chairman as more senators adopted a populist, antibank stance even as the White House launched a push to defend him.

headline: India Sees Terrorism Threats
summary: India put its security on high-alert following reports of a possible hijacking and paraglider attack. The U.K. separately raised its threat level to severe.

headline: GM Expects Sales Boost in China
summary: General Motors expects to sell more than two million units in China this year, a 10% to 15% rise from a year earlier.

headline: Ozawa Denies Allegations
summary: Democratic Party of Japan Secretary General Ichiro Ozawa told prosecutors that he wasn't aware of alleged mishandling of funds by his personal political funding management body.

headline: BOE, FDIC Boost Cooperation
summary: The Bank of England and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said they would increase their cooperation in dealing with distressed banks that operate in the U.S. and U.K.

headline: Sizing Up Wall Street Sheriffs
summary: New York's next attorney general won't be elected until November, but some of the contenders are taking a surprisingly conciliatory tone toward Wall Street.

headline: Obama Promises Action on Lobbyists
summary: Obama used his weekly radio address to assail a Supreme Court ruling this week on political advertisements, calling it a big victory for special interests and "devastating to the public interest."

headline: Road to Palm Springs: Very, Very Wet
summary: Flooding is the latest woe to afflict the once-glamorous Bob Hope Classic. Plus, "CSI" takes to the course and Georgia's Sea Island attracts a new tournament.

headline: A Glacier Meltdown
summary: The Himalayas and climate science.

headline: Pay Shift Augurs Ill for Shareholders
summary: Bank of America, Citi, Goldman, J.P. Morgan and Morgan Stanley said 2009 pay will include a greater percentage of stock than in previous years. That may cool anger but could harm shareholders.

headline: Chilly Forecasts Lift Natural Gas
summary: Dwindling inventories and forecasts of renewed frigid weather in the eastern U.S. lifted the natural-gas market, sending futures more than 3% higher ahead of the weekend.

headline: Union Membership Drops 10%
summary: Organized labor lost 10% of its members in the private sector last year, the largest decline in more than 25 years. The drop is on par with the decline in total employment but threatens to significantly limit labor's ability to influence elections and legislation.

headline: When Late Night Was Polite
summary: Johnny Carson's former head writer on how the comic great rose above the fray.

headline: Symetra Gains, Cellu Falls After IPOs
summary: Life insurer Symetra Financial gained while paper-products manufacturer Cellu Tissue Holdings declined during the year's first U.S. initial public offerings.

headline: Will New Rules Tame the Wall Street Tiger?
summary: President Obama's proposal to restrict the size and scope of banks certainly is good politics, but more inventive measures may be needed.

headline: Obama's Lead Blocker on Wall Street
summary: Obama has at least one buddy in the banking business: UBS's Robert Wolf, a big 2008 fund raiser who now serves as an outside White House adviser.

headline: Pick Your Poison
summary: From deadly snakes to toxic mushrooms, a look at history's poison garden.

headline: Macquarie Split Gets Shareholder Nod
summary: Macquarie Infrastructure Group's plan to split into two separately listed companies, potentially freeing up the $3.09 billion toll-road group's most valuable assets for takeover, was approved by investors.

headline: Bringing Home the Chicharrones
summary: The usually calm market for pork rinds is churning amid new U.S. regulations permitting imports of the crispy pig-skin snack from all around the world. See how chicharrones are made at one Chicago plant.

headline: Gold-Stocks Options Draw the Naysayers
summary: As the price of gold dropped lower, options traders signaled skepticism over the ability of gold stocks to climb above certain levels.

headline: Obama's Plan May Fail European Test
summary: No European country is likely to follow President Obama's lead in bank regulation without global agreement.

headline: Children's Books: The Lion and the Mouse
summary: Jerry Pinkney's new version of the classic tale "The Lion and the Mouse" has just won the Caldecott Medal for most distinguished American picture book. Meghan Cox Gurdon reviews.

headline: Meanwhile, Back at the Ranch
summary: Tom Nolan reviews Lori Armstrong's "No Mercy," a mystery-thriller about a female Army sniper named Mercy Gunderson, whose injuries in Iraq have sent her back home to South Dakota on medical leave. Instead of finding a little R&R, though, Mercy discovers plenty of trouble.

headline: U.S. Sues to Rescind Deal by Dean Foods
summary: Regulators filed an antitrust lawsuit seeking to undo Dean Food's 2009 acquisition of Foremost Farms's consumer-products division, saying the deal eliminated substantial competition in milk sales in three states.

headline: Finding Marc's Family
summary: A few days after the earthquake in Haiti, Marc Bigot set out from Miami to find his wife and two-year-old daughter in the devastation of Port-au-Prince.

headline: Obama Sharpens His Populist Tone
summary: President Obama tried to relaunch his political agenda with a populist attack on banks and insurance companies that signaled he would fight for his priorities going into the fall elections.

headline: Economic Team Feels Heat From Both Sides
summary: Summers, Geithner and Bernanke got their roles largely because of their experience tackling economic crises. That asset is now a liability.

headline: Program Trading
summary: Program trading in the week ended Jan. 15 amounted to 27.6% of New York Stock Exchange average daily volume of 2.2 billion shares, or 603.1 million program shares traded per day.

headline: Small Stocks Fall Into the Red for 2010
summary: Small-capitalization stocks went negative for the year Friday as slumping oil prices sent energy stocks tumbling and technology companies' earnings failed to meet investors' lofty expectations.

headline: White House Toughens Tone
summary: Coming off a difficult week, Obama has beefed up his political staff and is expected to deliver an uncompromising State of the Union.

headline: Butler Gets Five-Year Sentence
summary: A former Credit Suisse broker was sentenced for failing to tell corporate clients that he placed more than $1 billion of their money in auction-rate securities backed by subprime mortgages and other debt.

headline: California's Home Inventory Shrinks
summary: California's inventory of unsold, previously owned homes shrank to a five-year low in December, in another sign that the state may be coming out of its worst housing slump in decades.

headline: Duck and Cover
summary: overheard@wsj.com

headline: Magnificence on Cave Walls
summary: Inanke's prehistoric paintings are a celebration of life.

headline: Swiss Court Muddles UBS Settlement With U.S.
summary: A court panel ruled in favor of a U.S. taxpayer, saying UBS files on private-bank clients shouldn't be turned over to U.S. authorities.

headline: Obama Leaves Markets in a VIX
summary: Fear and greed are the odd couple whose constant squabbling dictates the direction of financial markets.

headline: Lessons From Singapore on Bank Bonuses
summary: Peter Stein writes that when it comes to bonuses, Wall Street could learn a thing or two from Singapore.

headline: Noonan: The New Political Rumbling
summary: Massachusetts may signal an end to old ways of fighting.

headline: All Nippon Airways Sees  Opportunity
summary: All Nippon Airways sees JAL's bankruptcy as an opportunity to grow its international business significantly and emerge even stronger than its larger rival.

headline: The Clinton Internet Doctrine
summary: 'An attack on one nation's networks can be an attack on all.'

headline: Bank Plan Renews Global Regulation Push
summary: U.S. moves to curb the size and spread of the biggest U.S. banks received a positive reaction from finance officials world-wide, appearing to jumpstart a faltering global debate on financial regulation.

headline: Moguls Skier Is Internet Mogul, Too
summary: Dale Begg-Smith is the top-ranked moguls skier in the world. The 25-year-old Canadian, who skis for Australia, is an Internet-ad mogul, too, and so rich he doesn't need sponsorship.

headline: Swine Flu Count Plagued by Flawed Data
summary: Initial projections of swine-flu illnesses and deaths exceeded subsequent tallies of the virus's impact in the U.S. Incomplete data and narrow samples could explain the disparity.

headline: Panera Bread's Strong Run
summary: Panera Bread has seen its shares outperform every major restaurant stock over the last 10 years. But how long can Panera's run last?

headline: Corrections and Amplifications
summary: Corrections & amplifications for Jan. 23, 2010.

headline: Executives See Bank Reform Hurdles
summary: Washington's stepped-up efforts to regulate banks raise worries that new regulation will slow economic recovery.

headline: Five Banks Fail; Year's Total at 9
summary: Regulators seized five banks in Florida, Missouri, New Mexico, Oregon and Washington, lifting the total number of failures this year to nine as financial institutions struggle with loan defaults and a weak economy.

headline: A Mercurial Advertising-Industry Pioneer
summary: Guy Day was co-founder of the breakthrough Los Angeles advertising agency Chiat/Day, renowned for creative campaigns such as the "1984" commercial introducing Apple's Macintosh computer.

headline: Harley-Davidson Faces Rough Ride
summary: Harley-Davidson swung to a loss in the fourth quarter and said demand could dip further in the coming year.

headline: Medicare Fraud Fighters
summary: Ask Encore columnist Kelly Greene on how seniors can help fight Medicare fraud.

headline: After ObamaCare
summary: How to resuscitate health reform after Massachusetts.

headline: Vexed Messaging
summary: Can texting during a play help improve the show? Terry Teachout explores ways to use texting to enhance performances rather than interfere with them.

headline: Greece Woes Spotlight Portugal Budget
summary: Greece's debt problems have boosted interest in Portugal's 2010 budget plan, which international investors will study for signs of similar fiscal frailty.

headline: Democrats May Table Big Health Goals
summary: After decades spent seeking universal health care, Democrats are considering moving legislation that would set that goal aside, yet again.

headline: RiskMetrics Puts Itself Up for Sale
summary: RiskMetrics Group has put itself on the auction block, and a number of media companies and private-equity firms have been contacted about a potential acquisition of the firm, which provides risk analysis, financial research and corporate-governance services.

headline: GE Profit Falls, but Hope Rises
summary: GE's profit fell 19% on a drop in earnings at its finance arm and NBC Universal. But overall results topped analysts' expectations. Immelt said the company saw "some encouraging signs at year-end."

headline: AmEx Falls 8.5%, Google Slips 5.7%
summary: Stocks fell sharply as fourth-quarter earnings from American Express, Google and Advanced Micro Devices topped analysts' estimates but failed to meet investors' lofty expectations.

headline: New York Glamour Goes Uptown
summary: Finicky Traveler Laura Landro finds that the Pierre, remade for $100 million, is swank, if not quite soundproof.

headline: Hershey Ends Cadbury Pursuit
summary: Hershey said it won't make a counterbid for Cadbury, an announcement that takes Kraft Foods a step closer to completing its acquisition of the U.K. confectioner.

headline: Defense Set to Press Gay-Marriage Case
summary: An attorney for gay couples that want to wed said he was pleased with the case so far, as backers of the ban prepared to open their direct line of defense.

headline: Ford's Focus: Don't Allow a Bay State Repeat
summary: The centrist Democrat thinks that his party needs to take a page from Bill Clinton's playbook.

headline: A Risqu√© IPO: FriendFinder
summary: Web site operator FriendFinder Networks is aggressively pitching its debut as a social-networking play. But its subscription model and adult nature could be off-putting.

headline: A Safer Way to Text on the Road
summary: Courtney Banks tests a service that lets her keep her eyes on the road while texting. She used Vlingo to dictate e-mails and text messages to her BlackBerry.

headline: Stock Selloff Gains Steam
summary: The broad-based selloff hit shares of everything from banks to materials companies to technology stocks, pushing the Dow industrials down 552.45 points, or 5.2%, during the past three sessions.

headline: Five Best Books on Families
summary: Novelist Pete Dexter ("Paris Trout," "Spooner") chooses his favorite works of fiction about family life, including Flannery O'Connor's short stories and Padgett Powell's coming-of-age novel, "Edisto."

headline: In Emerging-Market Debt, the Riskier the Better
summary: Fresh concerns over the global economic outlook aren't stopping investors from buying the riskiest emerging-market credits, even as they sell some higher-rated sovereigns.

headline: Abortion-Doctor Murder Trial Begins
summary: Prosecutors presented an account of their evidence against Scott Roeder, the man accused of killing one of the nation's few late-term abortion doctors, as his trial opened in Wichita.

headline: The Kids Will Be Alright
summary: In an adapted excerpt from "Four Hundred Years," Joel Kotkin argues that America is in the grip of major pessimism and the nation is on track to cope with challenges ahead better than any other country.

headline: The 19th Hole Goes Back to Golf
summary: Once-resplendent clubhouses are giving way to simpler, golf-only havens.

headline: Angry Squeals Over Pork-Rind Imports
summary: U.S. producers and state agriculture officials say a new rule loosening restrictions on pork rinds from Brazil and elsewhere will spread diseases.

headline: Too Big to Succeed?
summary: Buckling under the weight of its own expenses, the Cleveland Orchestra is in need of a new business model in these frustrating times for American symphonies.

headline: Some Hedge Funds See Opportunity
summary: Although investors and bankers widely greeted Obama's latest banking proposals with dismay, some sensed opportunity.

headline: The Hourglass Refigured
summary: In "Eternity Soup," Greg Critser goes "inside the quest to end aging" and finds everything from modern snake-oil salesmen to serious science. Shifting the sands of time, though, will not be easy. Matt Ridley reviews.

headline: A Rookie Quarterback in the Super Bowl?
summary: When rookie quarterbacks have started conference championships, the results haven't been pretty. Don't tell Mark Sanchez of the New York Jets.

headline: Morgan Stanley CEO: No Bonus
summary: Morgan Stanley Chief Executive James P. Gorman got no cash bonus for 2009, but could still walk away with stock-based compensation worth nearly $9 million.

headline: Google Founders to Sell Shares
summary: Google's co-founders each intend to sell about 5 million shares of the Internet search giant as part of a five-year stock trading plan, reducing their combined voting shares to 48%.

headline: Poison and Progress
summary: Modern science's race to stay ahead of global terrorists and political assassins began with some devious poisoners in the 19th and early 20th centuries.

headline: A Haitian's Quest to Save His Family
summary: Scores of Haitians are trying to flee Port-au-Prince, but Marc Bigot desperately wanted to get in. His goal: Find and reunite his family, then start rebuilding their lives abroad.
